description: Borrowed from Latin condoleo (“to suffer with another”).

verbs.description: condole (third-person singular simple present condoles, present participle condoling, simple past and past participle condoled)

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To express sympathetic sorrow; to lament in sympathy (with someone on something).
examples: […]  your friends would have cause to rejoyce rather than condole with you  […]
I not condole the dead, but those who’re living,
To whom the fear of death, gives cause of grieveing.

entries.meaning: (transitive) To say in an expression of sympathy.
examples: — So sad to look at his face, Miss Douce condoled.

entries.meaning: (transitive, India, chiefly obsolete in other dialects) To lament, grieve, bemoan (something).
examples: […]  compassion it selfe, comes to no great degree, if wee haue not felt, in some proportion, in our selues, that which wee lament and condole in another.
